#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Boston/Dorchester
#Text=So , you 've decided to visit Dorchester .
#Text=Congratulations !
#Text=Boston 's largest neighborhood had long been written off , dismissed as “ too dangerous ” by those who had never set foot here .
#Text=But longtime residents — or “ Dot Rats ” — have always known what the rest of Boston is beginning to rediscover .
#Text=An area close to downtown and the ocean , replete with beautiful parks , charming old architecture , and good public transit .
#Text=An area with a diverse and inclusive population , and additionally one of the more affordable spots in Boston .
#Text=When you consider these assets as a whole , it should come as no surprise that many are giving the neighborhood a second look .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Due to Dorchester 's large size it can be helpful for the traveller to think of it in two halves , north and south .
#Text=The northern half is more traditionally urban .
#Text=Houses are packed tightly together , people walk everywhere , all accompanied by the traffic and street noise one might expect .
#Text=Due to its proximity to downtown , the majority of new development is taking place here as well .
#Text=A huge cineplex , mall expansion , and many new condos are under construction as of 2016 .
#Text=The southern half , by contrast , continues to retain a more suburban feel .
#Text=City lots are a bit roomier , large condo buildings become less common while trees become more prevalent .
#Text=Driving is slightly less stressful and even necessary in some areas .
#Text=Stitching these two halves together is Dorchester Ave. Running from South Boston to Milton , Dot Ave is by far the neighborhood 's most powerful connector of people and places .
#Text=Yes , the big draw here is JFK Presidential Library , but to really experience Dorchester you should allow some time to investigate the people and places along this main street .
#Text=Neighborhoods
#Text=Again , Dorchester is huge .
#Text=If it were an independent city , it would be the 4th largest in the state .
#Text=Consider this a severely abridged list of just a few of the areas you may be interested in visiting .
#Text=Also take these names with a pinch of salt .
#Text=In a place this old , it can feel like every intersection has a special name or used to be called something else .
#Text=Ashmont : The general area around Ashmont station has been transformed in recent years , showcasing a rebuilt train station in 2011 and several new shops and restaurants .
#Text=The residential hills to the east and west of the station have deep Irish-American roots , and boast some of the finest houses anywhere in the city .
#Text=The Kennedys ' family home was in this area .
#Text=Ashmont is also one of the few areas in the south Dorchester where some mid-rise buildings have been going up .
#Text=It remains to be seen what type of impact they will have on the neighborhood .
#Text=You might also hear this area called Ashmont Hill or Peabody Square .
#Text=Another neighborhood , Adams Village , is very close by and has a similar Irish color .
#Text=Fields Corner : A variety of cultures meet and shop in this bustling commercial district .
#Text=Conveniently clustered shops selling a vast array of goods draw shoppers from nearby African-American , Vietnamese , and Irish enclaves .
#Text=During the warmer months the community park is in almost constant use with kids playing baseball , neighborhood festivals , or families barbecuing .
#Text=This area could also be considered the center of the Vietnamese community in Boston .
#Text=You can find many Vietnamese restaurants , places of worship , and community centers in the vicinity .
#Text=Lower Mills : On the shores of the Neponset River and functioning as Boston 's southern gateway , Lower Mills is decidedly upmarket .
#Text=Once the heart of chocolate manufacturing in the region , many picturesque old factory buildings have been painstakingly restored and converted into hundreds of luxury condos .
#Text=Following the arrival of new residents , new and old retailers alike have wasted no time updating their offerings in order to cater to this expanding community .
#Text=Lower Mills is also a great area to get outdoors .
#Text=Bike or walk along miles of trails and paved paths to check out some of the best green space Boston has to offer .
#Text=South Bay : Not an official neighborhood per se , but worth noting with all the construction going on in the area .
#Text=This part of Dorchester is by far its largest commercial district .
#Text=Anchored by big box stores like Target , Home Depot , and Best Buy among many others .
#Text=Its proximity to South Boston and the South End make it a neighborhood crossroads of sorts , and developers are pouring money in .
#Text=It 's surprisingly easy to drive here , due to the large parking lot and interstate highway nearby .
#Text=By public transit
#Text=The T 's Red Line runs frequent service to much of Dorchester .
#Text=Trains run about every 8 minutes , more during rush hour and less often at night .
#Text=JFK/UMass , Savin Hill , Fields Corner , Shawmut , and Ashmont stations all provide the neighborhood with convenient links to downtown Boston .
#Text=Be aware that the Red Line splits into two separate branches at JFK/UMass , so make sure you board an Ashmont bound train !
#Text=JFK/UMass also provides Dorchester with its only connection to several South Shore commuter rail lines .
#Text=Trains on the Greenbush , Kingston , and Middleborough/Lakeville lines stop here .
#Text=On the western border with Roxbury , the Fairmount commuter rail has stations at Newmarket , Uphams Corner , Four Corners/Geneva , and Talbot Avenue .
#Text=This line runs on an infrequent schedule , around once an hour , but the city planned to increase service by 2018 .
#Text=Ashmont station is the terminus of the Red Line , as well as the Ashmont-Mattapan High Speed Line .
#Text=This is a quaint 1940s era trolly system that locals continue to use everyday as they go about their business .
#Text=The trolley stops in Cedar Grove , and Butler before continuing on to Milton and Mattapan .
#Text=Ashmont is also the largest bus depot in Dorchester .
#Text=From here the #21 , #22 and #23 busses run to different points along the Orange Line .
#Text=Lines #215 , #217 , #240 , #245 are less frequent and run to Quincy and Milton .
#Text=While the #27 runs to Mattapan .
#Text=There are a few other bus connections from Fields Corner and JFK/UMass that also run to the Orange Line .
#Text=There is even a bus ( #18 ) that runs up and down Dorchester Ave , but good luck with that .
#Text=There are no bus connections from Savin Hill or Shamut stations .
